Zn-salen complexes with multiple hydrogen bonding donor and protic ammonium bromide: Bifunctional catalysts for CO2 fixation with epoxides at atmospheric pressure Xian-Dong Lang a Yi-Chen Yu a Liang-Nian He a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory and Institute of Elemento-Organic Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China State Key Laboratory and Institute of Elemento-Organic Chemistry Nankai University Tianjin 300071 China b Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering Nankai University Tianjin 300071 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Bifunctional Zn-salen complexes with multiple hydrogen bonding donors and protic ammonium bromides were developed as efficient catalysts for the formation of 4-phenyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one from styrene oxide and CO2. Owing to synergistic effects of multiple sites on epoxide activation (Lewis acidic zinc, phenolic hydroxyl group and protonated tertiary ammonium able to activate epoxide and bromide anion acting as a nucleophile), the easily-synthesized Zn-salen complexes showed outstanding performance at mild reaction conditions (CO2 0.1MPa, 100°C) using only 0.3mol% catalyst amount. Besides, this protocol is applicable to a variety of epoxides including internal epoxide, giving the corresponding cyclic carbonates in good to excellent yields. Notably, 200mmol-scale experiment was successfully conducted and TON of 49288±13 and TOF of 39473±8h−1 were achieved. Keywords Carbon dioxide fixation Cyclic carbonate Homogeneous catalysis Zn-salen complex Hydrogen bonding donors 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide is not only one of the greenhouse gases, but also can be regarded as a sustainable feedstock in organic synthesis due to the favourable characteristics of CO2 such as low cost, nontoxicity, nonflammability, easy accessibility and so on [1–3]. Therefore, efficient transformation of CO2 into value-added chemicals and fuels through constructing CN bond, CO bond and CC bond can meet the requirements of green chemistry and sustainable development [4–7]. One of the promising and most studied methodologies in this context is the formation of cyclic carbonates via the 100% atom-economical cycloaddition of epoxides with CO2, due to extensive applications of cyclic carbonates as economically competitive products, such as aprotic high-boiling polar solvents, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, precursors of polymeric materials, and fine chemicals [8–10]. Therefore, great progresses have been witnessed on development of various catalytic systems for this coupling reaction including metal-based catalysts e.g. metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [11,12], metal-salen complexe [13–23], metalloporphyrin [24–26], metal chloride [27], polyoxometalate [28], metal oxide [29,30] and metal-free catalysts containing hydroxyl [31–35], carboxyl [36–38] and so on [39,40], which activate the epoxide through hydrogen bonding interaction. Generally, metal catalysts exhibit superior performance compared to metal-free counterparts. In particular, metal-salen complexes have undoubtedly attracted much attention presumably owing to the intrinsic features with salen-ligand such as facile preparation, strong complexation ability with almost all metal ions and structural diversity and tunability [41–49]. From the mechanistic viewpoint, epoxide activation by Lewis acidic species or via hydrogen bonding interaction and subsequent ring-opening by nucleophilic attack of an halide anion e.g. bromide are two crucial steps [50]. In order to improve catalytic efficiency, incorporation of ionic moieties into the framework of salen ligand seems to be an advisable strategy as far as the structure-property correlation is concerned [51,52], so that an alternative process not only avoids decomposition of cocatalyst for example, tetrabutyl ammonium bromide TBAB via retro-Menschutkin reaction [13], but also facilitates the product separation and catalyst reusability. In this aspect, Jiang and co-workers have developed a Lewis acid-base bifunctional Zn-salen complex through covalent linkage of the tertiary amine i.e. N-methylhomopiperazine [16], which can be used as efficient and recoverable catalyst for this cycloaddition. In this system, the epoxide is likely activated by the Lewis acidic zinc center, and N-methylhomopiperazine species presumably attacks at the less-hindered carbon atom of the epoxides. Additionally, the ligands can be modified by quaternary ammonium group, producing bifunctional monometallic [17] and bimetallic [13,61,63] Al-salen complexes, reported by Lu and North, respectively. For the thus synthesized bifunctional monometallic Al-salen complex, a high TON of 116230 was achieved at 2.5MPa CO2 with the reaction time of 48h. Besides, oxazolidinones were also obtained in high yields with complete configuration retention. The bimetallic Al-salen complex can be supported on silica to afford an equally efficient and heterogeneous bifunctional catalyst, leading to facilitate the catalyst recovery and product separation [19]. Furthermore, the silica particle size plays an important role in the catalytic activity. Lee and co-workers have developed the bifunctional Co-salen complex modified with quaternary ammonium salt as efficient and thermally robust catalyst for the copolymerization of propylene oxide with CO2. High TOF (up to 3500h−1) and TON (up to 14500) were attained [23]. The introduction of halide anion can also be operated via the alkylation at the pyridyl-N atom, producing bifunctional alkylated Zn(salpyr) complexes [52]. In this aspect, imidazolium moieties containing polyethylene oxide (PEO) chains can also be embodied in to endow the synthesized bifunctional catalyst with “CO2-philic” capability [15]. Most recently, Jing et al. have developed an efficient protocol for asymmetric coupling reaction of CO2 and epoxides [18], using a series of chiral SalenCo(III)Y catalysts supported on the alkyl imidazole ionic liquids at room temperature and 1.2MPa CO2. The influence of axial anion Y on catalytic activity followed the order of OAc− >CF3CO2 − >CCl3CO2 − >OTs−, whereas on enantioselectivity OTs− >OAc− >CCl3CO2 − >CF3CO2 −. Our group has developed a bifunctional cobalt-salen complex containing a Lewis acidic metal and two quaternary phosphonium salt units anchored on the salen ligand. This is an excellent catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides without the utilization of additional organic solvents under relatively elevated CO2 pressure (4MPa) [14]. As a kind of nontoxic, easily available metal with strong Lewis acidity, Zn has been a well exploited metal for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides [53–55]. In view of the cooperative effect of both the epoxides activation by Lewis acidic species together with hydrogen bonding interaction, and nucleophilic ability of the bromide anion, a series of bifunctional Zn-salen complexes with multiple hydrogen bonding donor and protic ammonium bromide were synthesized and evaluated the activity for the cycloaddition between epoxides and CO2, as depicted in Scheme 1 a. Because of the synergistic effects of multiple sites on epoxide activation illustrated in Scheme 1b (Lewis acidic zinc, phenolic hydroxyl group and protonated tertiary ammonium able to activate epoxide and bromide anion acting as nucleophile), Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am) showed outstanding catalytic performance at 0.1MPa CO2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods CO2 with a purity of 99.999% was commercially available. Propylene oxide was obtained from Alfa Aesar, while other epoxides, hydrobromic acid, pyridine, N,N-diethylethylenediamine, salicylaldehyde, 3,5-Bis(1,1-dimethylethyl)-2-hydroxy-benzaldehyde were purchased from Aladdin and used as received. 2,3,4-Trihydroxybenzaldehyde and 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide were obtained from Bide Pharmatech. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker 400MHz spectrometer using CDCl3 or DMSO-d6 as solvent referenced to CHCl3 (7.26ppm) or DMSO-d6 (2.50ppm). 13C NMR spectra were recorded at 100.6MHz in CDCl3 (or DMSO-d6 ) using CDCl3 (77.0ppm) (or DMSO-d6 , 39.5ppm) as an internal reference. GC analysis were performed on a Shimadzu GC-2014 equipped with a capillary column (RTX-50 30m×0.25μm) using a flame ionization detector. High resolution mass spectrometry was conducted using a Varian 7.0T FTICR-MS by ESI technique. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrophotometer with KBr pellets. In situ FT-IR was collected on a Mettler Toledo React IR ic10, Sicomp (Silicon) ATR probe, using ic IR analysis system. The probe is placed in the middle of the reaction mixture, which is constantly stirred by magnetic bar, and the spectra are collected in situ during the whole process. All the products were characterized and identified by comparison with those reported in the literature [14,35,39]. 2.2 Typical procedure for the preparation of bifunctional Zn-salen complexes The four bifunctional Zn-salen complexes listed in Scheme 1 were synthesized according to the reported procedure with a minor modification [69–72]. Take the synthesis of Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am) as an example which is shown in Scheme 2 , an solution of N,N-diethylethylenediamine hydrobromide [C2NH2am][Br] (2mmol, 0.3942g) in 5mL ethanol was added dropwise to a solution of 2,3,4-trihydroxybenzenaldehyde (2.2mmol, 0.3388g). After stirring at 70°C overnight, Zn(OAc)2·H2O (2mmol, 0.432g) was added to the flask in portions. And immediately, large amount of yellow solid formed, which was then filtrated and dried under vacuum at 70°C for one day. The reaction mixture was stirred at 100°C for the desired time under an atmosphere of CO2 (99.999%, balloon). After the reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, and added biphenyl (3mmol, 0.4626g) as internal standard for GC yield determination. For gram-scale operations, in a typical experiment, Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am) (0.03mol%, 1.1mg) and epichlorohydrin were introduced into the inner glass tube successively. Afterwards, the mixed gas pressure was adjusted to 3MPa at 120°C by charging CO2 three times. The reaction mixture was stirred for desired time at 120°C. When the reaction finished, the reactor was cooled in ice-water, and CO2 was ejected slowly. Consequently, our exploratory experiments started using styrene oxide (1a) as the benchmark substrate under 0.1MPa CO2 to evaluate the catalytic activity of the bifunctional Zn-salen complexes as shown in Scheme 1a. The results are summarized in Table 1 . Obviously, no reaction occurred in the absence of any catalyst (entry 1). 4-Phenyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one (2a) was obtained in only 6% yield in the presence of Zn(salC2NH2Py) with pyridine-based ionic moiety (entry 2). It was reported that hydroxyl [31–35], carboxyl [36–38] and amino [39,40]-containing electrophiles could interact with the epoxide via hydrogen bonding interaction, thus facilitating the ring opening of the epoxide by bromide anion. With this idea in mind, two bifunctional Zn-salen complexes e.g. Zn(salC2NH2Am), Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am) with multiple hydrogen bonding donors such as protonated tertiary ammonium and phenolic hydroxyl group were prepared for this purpose. Gratifyingly, the introduction of such hydrogen bonding donors into the ligand led to the remarkable increase in 2a yield (entries 3, 4). The bulky alkyl substituents on the aromatic ring could improve the solubility of Zn(t-Bu-salC2NH2Am) in styrene oxide and thus enhances its activity [61–64] (entry 3 vs 5). Poor solubility of the complex in the reaction mixture was observed when polar ionic group was tethered into the salen ligand, leading to lower activity compared to the binary system [15,24–26,65]. In this context, a suitable solvent is necessary to perform the reaction smoothly. Among the conventional organic solvents examined, DMF gave the best results (entries 6–9, 4). To explore the respective role of Lewis acidic zinc and multiple hydrogen bonding donors, ZnBr2 and ligand of Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am) i.e. N,N-diethyl-2-((2,3,4-trihydroxybenzylidene)amino) ethanaminium bromide were utilized as catalyst for the benchmark reaction, affording 37% and 20% yield of 2a. The results demonstrated the superior of Lewis acidic zinc beyond multiple hydrogen bonding donors and Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am) beyond ZnBr2 and its corresponding ligand. Subsequently, the influences of the reaction parameters including reaction time, temperature and catalyst loading on the reaction were investigated as listed in Table 2 . It can be easily seen that the reaction actually completed within 16h, no further increase in 2a yield was observed with prolonging reaction time (entries 1–4, Table 2). The catalyst loading can be decreased to 0.3 mol% (entry 5 vs 2). To be delighted, Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am) also gave a good result even with as low as 0.1 mol% amount relative to 1a (entry 6). Furthermore, the result remained almost unchanged when the temperature was decreased from 120°C to 100°C (entry 5 vs 7). A sharp decline in 2a yield was observed when the temperature further decreased to 80°C (entries 5, 7 vs 8). In addition, DMF was reported to promote the epoxide/CO2 coupling reaction under the supercritical conditions [66,67]. However, DMF itself was inactive in this study (CO2 0.1MPa, 100°C, 16h) and just serves as solvent (entry 9). To investigate the effect of integrating multiple functional groups such as phenolic hydroxyl group, protic ammonium bromide in one salen molecule, the catalytic performance of simple physical mixture such as Zn(salC2NH2Am)/1,2-benzenediol and Zinc(II) [N,Ń-ethylene-bis(salicylidenediamine)] Zn(SAL)/TBAB/1,2-benzenediol were subsequently evaluated. Lower yield was afforded compared to Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am), demonstrating the superiority of integrating functional groups in one molecule (entries 10–11). Having established the suitable reaction conditions, the generality and utility of this approach were investigated using various epoxides. As summarized in Table 3 , the terminal epoxides can be efficiently transformed to the corresponding cyclic carbonates in high yield and excellent selectivity (entries 1–6, Table 3). This protocol can be applied to the synthesis of various cyclic carbonates containing electron-withdrawing and electron-donating substituents in almost quantitative yields, suggesting potential application in industry. Due to steric hindrance, carboxylation of cyclohexene oxide (CHO) remains a grand challenge. The target product 2g was formed in only 14% yield. Fortunately, nice result was obtained under 3MPa pressure (entry 7). To exploit the catalytic performance of Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am), 20g-scale reactions of epichlorohydrin 1c with CO2 were conducted using various catalyst/substrate ratios i.e. Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am): 1c. The results are summarized in Table 4 . Relatively high value of TON (26496 and 43906) and TOF (1019h−1 and 1688h−1) were obtained with 51mmol and 76mmol 1c, respectively (entries 1, 2). To our delight, this bifunctional zinc salen complex Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am) demonstrated high catalytic activity even with 200mmol (18.504g) scale (entry 4, Table 4). The maximum TON (turnover number) and TOF (turnover frequency) reached up to 49288±13 and 39473±8h−1, respectively (entries 3, 4). This is one of the most effective salen complexes reported to date for the epoxide/CO2 coupling, but shows lower activity compared with the highly symmetrical and bifunctional porphyrin complexes developed by Ema and coworkers [24–26]. To monitor the process of gram-scale operation, in situ FT-IR spectroscopy was conducted at 0.1MPa CO2 (Fig. 1 ). An induction period was observed under solvent-free conditions, while disappeared with the addition of DMF, implying that 2a may act as the solvent in the absence of any conventional solvent. In the FT-IR spectra, the characteristic peak at 876cm−1 of the epoxy ring declined gradually, indicating the consumption of 1a. Meanwhile, the appearance of adsorption peaks at 1065cm−1, 1159cm−1 (asymmetrical CO vibration) and 1810cm−1 (CO stretching vibration) were suggestive of the formation of 4-phenyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one 2a. Based on experimental results in this study and previous reports [31,39,52,68], a tentative mechanism involving bromide anion as nucleophile, multiple hydrogen bonding donors and Lewis acidic center is illustrated in Scheme 3 . Firstly, the epoxide is activated by the Lewis acidic center (i.e. zinc), protonated tertiary ammonium and phenolic hydroxyl group through hydrogen bonding interaction, thus resulting in accelerating the ring-opening of the epoxide. In deed, the experimental results (entry 2 vs 3, entry 3 vs 4 and entry 6 vs 11, Table 1) indicate the key role of catalytic sites i.e. protonated tertiary ammonium, phenolic hydroxyl group and Lewis acidic species, respectively. Besides, the superiority of integrating functional groups in one molecule is also demonstrated (entry 7 vs 11–12, Table 2). All the above mentioned experimental results validate the cooperative effects of the three different catalytic sites (Lewis acidic center, protonated tertiary ammonium and phenolic hydroxyl group). Simultaneously, the nucleophilic attack of bromide anion at the less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of the epoxide affords the ring-opened intermediate B. Subsequently, nucleophilic attack of the intermediate B at CO2 produces the acyclic metal carbonate species C. Finally, intramolecular ring-closure of C furnishes the cyclic carbonate as target product. 4 Conclusions As a kind of low toxic, readily available metal, Zn has been well exploited in the cycloaddition of epoxides and CO2. Based on “Lewis acid-base cooperative catalysis” principle, a series of single-component bifunctional salen-Zn complexes bearing various functional groups were tested the catalytic activity for epoxides/CO2 coupling. Originating from co-existence of Lewis acidic zinc center, hydrogen bonding donors e.g. phenolic hydroxyl group, protonated tertiary ammonium in combination of nucleophilic species i.e. bromide anion in one molecule, Zn(OH-salC2NH2Am) showed high catalytic activity for the formation of cyclic carbonates from epoxides and CO2, which promoted the reactions at 0.1MPa CO2. High TON and TOF value (49288±13 and 39473±8h−1, respectively) were also reached. This process represents an alternative approach for greener chemical fixation of CO2 to afford valuable compounds with potential industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Bifunctional Zn-salen complexes with multiple hydrogen bonding donors and protic ammonium bromides were developed as efficient catalysts for the formation of 4-phenyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one from styrene oxide and CO2. Owing to synergistic effects of multiple sites on epoxide activation (Lewis acidic zinc, phenolic hydroxyl group and protonated tertiary ammonium able to activate epoxide and bromide anion acting as a nucleophile), the easily-synthesized Zn-salen complexes showed outstanding performance at mild reaction conditions (CO2 0.1MPa, 100°C) using only 0.3mol% catalyst amount. Besides, this protocol is applicable to a variety of epoxides including internal epoxide, giving the corresponding cyclic carbonates in good to excellent yields. Notably, 200mmol-scale experiment was successfully conducted and TON of 49288±13 and TOF of 39473±8h−1 were achieved.
coredata.dc:title: Zn-salen complexes with multiple hydrogen bonding donor and protic ammonium bromide: Bifunctional catalysts for CO2 fixation with epoxides at atmospheric pressure
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
